awd_titl_txt: Investigating language contact and shift through experimentally-oriented documentation
awd_abstract_narration:
It is well-known that when speakers of different languages are in contact with one another, the structures of these languages can and do change. Words and even grammatical structures can be borrowed from one language into another, and the structures of the languages can also converge into something new. One potential outcome of contact is language shift: when speakers cease to speak their ancestral language in favor of a new (generally more economically or politically advantageous) one. Language shift is known to be a major driver behind language endangerment and loss, but the transition from language contact (sustained bi- or multilingualism) to language loss (the abandonment of one of the languages) is not well-understood. The current project aims to document language contact in progress by combining traditional documentation methods with new questions and approaches borrowed from laboratory psycholinguistics, in order to better understand the social and cognitive factors that drive shift. Qualitative methodology, including interviews and elicitation, are combined with quantitative and experimental methods for a systematic investigation of the factors that influence language contact and shift. This project helps understand the linguistic and psycholinguistic processes at work in language loss and can aid in developing strategies to promote healthy language contact. This is of enormous value especially to marginalized communities experiencing and attempting to forestall linguistic and, in turn, cultural loss.

This project studies the changes that are currently taking place in urban versus village settings for a set of endangered languages spoken in the northeastern part of Russia. The region provides an excellent testing ground because of the variety of languages and different contact ecologies found in the Sakha Republic and the Chukotka Autonomous Region. Urbanization, a known factor in language shift, is occurring rapidly here, and the capital Yakutsk is the fastest growing northern city.  The region provides excellent conditions to study the varying roles of cognitive and social factors because it has two majority languages, one national (Russian) and one regional (Sakha, a Turkic language) used in education, government and all local domains. The study focuses on language contact between Russian, Sakha and three minority endangered languages: Even and Evenki (both Tungusic), Chukchi (Chukotko-Kamchatkan) and Yukaghir (possibly Uralic), which are structurally different and can illustrate how linguistic patterns affect change. Although these languages are endangered and in need of urgent documentation, their speaker populations are still robust enough to provide a sufficient sample for rigorous statistical analysis, and to document different stages of shift. Well-controlled production and comprehension experiments will be conducted, focusing on three linguistic parameters: word order (and its interaction with case marking), case marking and alignment, and subordination strategies, with particular attention to the linguistic encoding of spatial relations. To complement data collected from controlled experiments, data will be collected from spontaneous conversation in order to document the dynamic multilingual practices in these contact ecologies. All data will be subject to rigorous statistical modeling. The project includes yearly training workshops and in-field experience to prepare local students and linguists in language documentation and psycholinguistics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has examined language shift in Arctic Indigenous communities in Greenland and far northeastern Siberia. We find social, economic, historical, and political factors that drive shift, the situation where speakers give up the language of their ancestors in favor of another language that is generally more widely used, more prestigious, and has social and political power. In Greenland we have discovered a complex dynamic language ecology that is evolving rapidly due to massive urbanization and influx of outsiders, both seasonal and more permanent immigrants, who bring with them different languages and cultures. A key result is that in the capital Nuuk, much of the population is currently trilingual, using Kalaallisut (Greenlandic), Danish and—increasingly English. In Greenland recent improvements in internet connectivity have facilitated an influx of online content in English; children and teenagers now learn English rapidly through the internet and youtube in particular.

The language ecologies of Siberia present a different picture. Here we have examined different Indigenous languages—Chukchi, Dolgan, Even and Sakha; speakers of all of these languages are in contact with Russian. We find that speakers of smaller minority languages are shifting to Russian or Sakha; Sakha is the only language besides Russian that has this status. As in Greenland, increased internet connectivity and urbanization foster language shift, and here too parents and teachers point to the impact of youtube, and in particular programming aimed at children, as a pathway for introducing Russian and English into the household.

In order to examine the linguistic changes that take place during language shift, we needed to obtain data that is directly comparable across speakers and across differing speech communities and languages. To that end, we developed experimental methodologies for fieldwork in Arctic Indigenous communities, and further created and implemented methods for assessing speaker proficiency in conditions of language contact and shift with a focus on these minoritized communities. Our research questions zero in on determining which linguistic structures are vulnerable and which are resilient. We have attempted to answer key questions about structural change in shift ecologies, including whether such changes result in simplification, restructuring, or simply loss.

We show language shift across all languages investigated in Siberia. There is extensive structural restructuring in Chukchi, which is currently highly endangered. Perhaps unexpectedly, although the restructuring is the result of language shift toward and pressure from Russian, the changes themselves appear to be language-internal. That is, Chukchi restructuring involves the use of Chukchi resources and does not exhibit direct transfer from Russian. In Even and Sakha, we find significant changes in word order but no subsequent typological restructuring. In Sakha, there is strong evidence of the loss of light verbs, a change more advanced among younger speakers and considerably more advanced for shifting speakers. In Even, we find significant loss of converbs in general, with subordination being done with finite verb forms on a Russian model, or with clauses combined by parataxis and/or coordination. In low proficiency speakers, we find significant loss of case marking, including the loss of core cases (accusative). There is extensive code-mixing across the board, by highly proficient speakers as well as low proficiency speakers. The nature of the code-mixing differs, however, with the weaker speakers switching to Russian (or Sakha for some Even) because they cannot express something in the target language. More proficient speakers simply use different languages as available in their linguistic repertoire.

More surprising is a shift toward English in Nuuk (Greenland), with younger speakers (ages 20-25 in our pool) using a mix of Kalaallisut and English in daily speech. English is heard in multiple domains in Nuuk and is used by even young children playing out on the street. We have gathered enough data, both systematically through elicitations, focused experiments and recording of free conversation, along with observational data while participating in daily life, to be convinced of significant changes underway in language usage in Nuuk. Our consultants report similar changes in areas with high levels of tourism, but all consistently say that such changes are most extensive, most advanced, in Nuuk.

A core goal of this project is training future scientists. To that end, we have run training workshops in Siberia and in Chicago, and have engaged undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Chicago, in Greenland and in Siberia in the actual research: conducting fieldwork and experiments, data transcription and analysis, and presentation of research results. The project has also fostered long-term, sustainable collaborations with students, junior and senior scholars in all locations.
